# SPAM vs HAM

In dieser Aufgabe besch√§ftigen wir uns mit dem Spam vs. Ham Klassifizierungsproblem.

```{r}
# Einlesen des Datensatz und erstellen der Feature-Matrix
trainFeatures <- as.matrix(read.table(file='data/preparedFeatures/train-features.txt'))
trainLabels <- as.matrix(read.table(file='data/preparedFeatures/train-labels.txt'))
testFeatures <- as.matrix(read.table(file='data/preparedFeatures/test-features.txt'))
testLabels <- as.matrix(read.table(file='data/preparedFeatures/test-labels.txt'))

head(trainLabels)
head(trainFeatures)

# Now we want to build a feature matrix where each row represents a file (message), each column a word,
# and each entry the frequency of that specific word inside the message.
# For this:
# the index of the label in test/trainLabels indicates the file id, so if test/trainLabels[5]=1, the # # message with file id=5 is spam. Additionally, these are ordered. The top half is always ham, while the
# bottom half is always spam. 
# in the same way, the test/trainFeatures are ordered by file id (V1), followed by word id (V2) and word count (V3) of
# that specific word inside of the file with id V1.
# Probably best way: slice the train/testFeatures on different values of the V1 Column and
# use resulting smaller matrices to fill in the
# row vector at V1 of the feature matrix with the number from V3 at column position from V2

trainFeatureMatrix <- matrix()
testFeatureMatrix <- matrix()
```
